Given \(X \sim \text{Exp}(1)\) and \(Y|X=x \sim \text{Poisson}(x)\), the variance of \(Y\) can be found using the law of total variance: \(\text{Var}(Y) = \mathbb{E}[\text{Var}(Y|X)] + \text{Var}(\mathbb{E}[Y|X])\).

Since \(\text{Var}(Y|X=x) = x\) and \(\mathbb{E}[Y|X=x] = x\), we have:
- \(\mathbb{E}[\text{Var}(Y|X)] = \mathbb{E}[X] = 1\),
- \(\text{Var}(\mathbb{E}[Y|X]) = \text{Var}(X) = 1\).

Adding these gives \(\text{Var}(Y) = 1 + 1 = 2\).
